Core UOR Axioms

The Seven Core UOR Axioms codify the essential properties ensuring that any Unique Factorization Domain (UFD) supports a fully coherent, observer‚Äêaware, prime‚Äêcoordinate representation. These axioms act as the logical scaffolding underpinning the entire Prime Framework:

  1. Intrinsic Primes

    Statement. A set P of atomic elements exists such that no element in P factors further under composition in the domain.

    Analysis. These primes serve as the alphabet for every object's unique decomposition. Units (identity elements) are excluded from P, leaving irreducible generators of the composition monoid.

  2. Unique Factorization (UFD Axiom)

    Statement. Every non‚Äëunit object admits a finite product decomposition into primes, and this decomposition is unique up to reordering of factors.

    Analysis. Guarantees each object has one and only one prime signature‚Äîessential for defining unambiguous coordinates.

  3. Prime-Coordinate Homomorphism

    Statement. There exists an injective homomorphism œÜ: ùí∞ ‚Üí ‚Ñ§^P mapping each object to its exponent vector over primes, satisfying œÜ(X‚àòY)=œÜ(X)+œÜ(Y).

    Analysis. This functorial map linearizes composition, turning multiplicative relations into vector addition and enabling algebraic and geometric techniques.

  4. Canonical Representation

    Statement. The image œÜ(X) is a unique, lossless encoding that does not depend on numeral base or observer frame and achieves the minimal coherence norm among all representations.

    Analysis. Establishes the fully factored prime form as the intrinsic normal form for every object.

  5. Coherence Norm

    Statement. Equip ‚Ñ§^P with the norm measuring simplicity of the prime exponent vector.

    Analysis. Any non‚Äëprime grouping increases this norm, making the prime decomposition the shortest (most coherent) vector.

  6. Coherence Inner Product

    Statement. Define an inner product, making the exponent space a Euclidean vector space with orthonormal prime axes.

    Analysis. Enables distances, angles, and projections in prime-coordinate geometry, underpinning spectral and geometric interpretations.

  7. Trilateral Coherence

    Statement. Every valid description of an object incorporates three coherent aspects: its intrinsic prime-coordinate structure, the dynamics (composition rules), and the observer reference frame.

    Analysis. By formalizing observers as a bundle with frame transformations preserving œÜ, UOR ensures invariant intrinsic data while accommodating perspective shifts.

  8. Universal Mapping Property

    Statement. The prime-coordinate homomorphism is the initial object among all monoid homomorphisms to abelian groups that send units to zero.

    Proof Sketch. Since œÜ is surjective onto the free abelian group and units lie in its kernel, any œà factors through the quotient using a suitable mapping. Uniqueness follows from the fact that the p-th basis element must map to œà(p), fixing the homomorphism on generators.

    Examples of Factorization through œÜ

    • Liouville Function Œª: Multiplicative function assigning +1 or -1 based on number of prime factors

    • p-adic Valuation: For fixed prime p‚ÇÄ, measures its exponent in factorization

    • Totient Function œÜ‚ÇÄ: Euler's function counting numbers coprime to n

    These illustrate that any classical multiplicative arithmetic function arises via composition with œÜ. The Universal Mapping Property thus characterizes œÜ as the source of all multiplicative invariants.

Together, these axioms guarantee that every object can be assigned an unambiguous prime‚Äêcoordinate spectrum, situated in a Euclidean lattice and coherently contextualized by an observer frame. This trilogy of structure, dynamics, and perspective forms a robust foundation for exploring deep connections‚Äîfrom number theory to quantum geometry‚Äîand for forging new mathematical and physical vistas beyond the classical horizon.
